head.supplied: [ ¶ Dr Mueller has sent me the enclosed two printed items for you, ¶ Printed items not identified. ¶ ¶ which I send on to you herewith. The good friend would soon have died recently as a result of a ...

div.p:
MS not seen; text given here extracted from Tkach, Neubauer & Roser (2022), Brief
27.
[Herr Dr. Müller hat mir die beifolgenden beiden Drucksachen für Sie gesandt, die ich Ihnen hiermit zustelle. Der gute Freund wäre kürzlich bald in Folge einer Erkältung die er sich beim Suchen von Wasserpflanzen zuzog, gestorben. Nachher hätte er bald seine Stelle verloren, da alle Deutschen missliebig wurden, weil ein Hannoveraner an der Spitze der Revolution stand. Er hat aber dies Missgeschick auch überstanden und so hoffe ich, dass es ihm auch ferner gut ergehen werde. — Den ersten Report über seine Reisen hat Müller unvorsichtigerweise einem nach Europa reisenden Kaufmann mitgegeben, der ihn aber nicht abgeliefert hat, es thut mir leid, dass auch ein für Sie bestimmtes Exemplar dabei war.

Ich bin wohl für die beiden Hefte der Linnaea bei Ihnen in der Schuld, will diese aber erst noch vergrössern, bevor ich die abtrage. Dr. Müller schreibt mir, er wünsche den
ganzen
Jahrgang der Linnaea von 1853 bis 1854 zu erhalten. Von Band X habe ich Heft IV u V liegen, möchten Sie die Güte haben u mir das Uebrige davon zuschicken u dann den Preis anzugeben, den ich Ihnen bald zustellen werde. Wenn es angeht, wäre es mir lieb, die Hefte bis zum 20 oder 21 d. M. hier zu haben, da ich am 22 eine Kiste für Dr. Müller abschicke.]

[Dr Mueller has sent me the enclosed two printed items for you,
Printed items not identified.
which I send on to you herewith. The good friend would soon have died recently as a result of a cold he caught while looking for water plants.
M contracted a severe chill, which he later described as 'gastrischem Fieber' [gastric fever], during the latter stages of his recent expedition into the Victorian Alps; see M to F. Krichauff, 9 March 1855,and M to W. Haines, 10 March 1855.
Afterwards he would soon have lost his position, as all Germans were unpopular because a Hanoverian was at the head of the revolution.
The Eureka rebellion. The Hanoverian leader was Friedrich Wern;see Wehner
(2017),pp.51-5.The threat to M's positionhad little if anything to do to do with the rebellion butwas financial, with major cut-backs proposed in government expenditure, including its various scientific services.
However, he has also survived this misfortune and so I hope that henceforth he will even fare well. — Mueller incautiously gave the first report on his travels
B55.01.01?
to a merchant travelling to Europe, but he has not delivered it; I'm sorry that a copy intended for you was also included.

I am probably in debt to you for the two parts of Linnaea, but I will add to it first before I repay it. Dr Mueller writes me that he would like to receive the
entire
volume of Linnaea from 1853 to 1854. I have parts IV and V of volume X. Would you be so kind as to send me the rest of them and then let me know the price, which I will sendyou soon. If it is possible, I would appreciate it if you could have the issues here by the 20th or 21st of this month, because I am sending off a box for Dr Mueller on the 22nd.]
